question: Will Fast and Fatal win the 2025 Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting?
reasoning:
Based on the information gathered, here are some key points:

1. **Finalists and Prize Structure**: The Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting honors investigative reporting that promotes effective and ethical government conduct. The winner receives $25,000, and five finalists receive $10,000 each. The prize is administered by the Shorenstein Center at Harvard University.

2. **Current Status**: 'Fast and Fatal' by Jennifer Gollan and Susie Neilson of The San Francisco Chronicle is one of the finalists for the 2025 prize. The winner will be announced on April 3, 2025.

3. **No Current Predictions or Announcements**: There are no current predictions or announcements indicating which finalist might win the prize. The information available does not provide any specific insights into the likelihood of 'Fast and Fatal' winning over other finalists.

Given the lack of specific predictions or insider information about the likelihood of 'Fast and Fatal' winning, it is challenging to assign a high probability to its success. However, being a finalist already indicates a strong entry.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.2

sitename: Goldsmith Awards

# The Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting

## About the award

The annual Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting honors investigative reporting that best promotes more effective and ethical conduct of government, the making of public policy, or the practice of politics. The winner receives $25,000, and five finalists receive $10,000. Prize money is paid directly to the journalists, not the news organizations. While the subject can address issues of foreign policy, a submission qualifies only if it has an impact on public policy in the United States at the national, regional or local level.

Financial support for the Goldsmith Awards Program is provided by an annual grant from the Goldsmith Fund of the Greenfield Foundation. The program is administered by the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University’s Kennedy School of Government.

## Criteria and Rules

### Criteria

The annual Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting honors investigative reporting that best promotes more effective and ethical conduct of government, the making of public policy, or the practice of politics. The winner receives $25,000, and five finalists receive $10,000. While the subject can address issues of foreign policy, a submission qualifies only if it has an impact on public policy in the United States at the national, regional or local level. Entries from small and mid-size publications and comparable broadcast/online outlets are encouraged.

### Prize Money

The winning entry receives $25,000, and five finalist entries receive $10,000 each. Prize money is paid directly to credited authors of the winning/nominated entries, not their organizations.

#### Submission Info

---
title: 2025 Goldsmith Awards Ceremony
url: https://iop.harvard.edu/events/2025-goldsmith-awards-ceremony
hostname: harvard.edu
description: The annual Goldsmith Awards, presented by the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics, and Public Policy at Harvard Kennedy School, honors public service journalism that has had an impact on United States public policy and the functioning of government. Each year the awards honor six reporting teams (five finalists and one winner) for the Investigative Reporting Prize, one award for the Explanatory Reporting Prize, and two awards for books published in the last year on a topic at the intersection of media, politics, and public policy.The 2025 Career Awardee for Excellence in Journalism is Anderson Cooper, award-winning CNN anchor and CBS 60 Minutes correspondent. Cooper will be the featured speaker at this year’s ceremony, he will share his insights in a “fireside chat” with Shorenstein Center Director Nancy Gibbs, followed by a brief question-and-answer session with the audience.The in-person event will be livestreamed at GoldsmithAwards.org and ShorensteinCenter.org.More information on The Goldsmith Awards Program can be found here: https://goldsmithawards.org/Sponsored by: Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy
sitename: iop.harvard.edu
date: 2025-04-03
tags: ['politics, government, service, harvard, education, Kennedy']
---
# 2025 Goldsmith Awards Ceremony

### Description

The annual Goldsmith Awards, presented by the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics, and Public Policy at Harvard Kennedy School, honors public service journalism that has had an impact on United States public policy and the functioning of government. Each year the awards honor six reporting teams (five finalists and one winner) for the [Investigative Reporting Prize](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-investigative-reporting/), one award for the [Explanatory Reporting Prize](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-explanatory-reporting/), and [two awards for books](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-book-prize/) published in the last year on a topic at the intersection of media, politics, and public policy.

[The 2025 Career Awardee for Excellence in Journalism is Anderson Cooper](https://shorensteincenter.org/anderson-cooper-honored-2025-goldsmith-career-award-excellence-journalism/), award-winning CNN anchor and CBS 60 Minutes correspondent. Cooper will be the featured speaker at this yea…

# Announcements

The Goldsmith Awards Program, launched in 1991, has as its goal the encouragement of a more insightful and spirited public debate about government, politics and the press.

title: Announcing the winner of the inaugural Goldsmith Prize for Explanatory Reporting | Shorenstein Center
url: https://shorensteincenter.org/announcing-winner-inaugural-goldsmith-prize-explanatory-reporting/

description: The Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy is pleased to announce that The Washington Post’s Opinions series “Who is Government?” is the winner of the inaugural Goldsmith Prize for Explanatory Reporting. The prize will be awarded at the 2025 Goldsmith Awards ceremony on April 3 at the JFK Jr. Forum at Harvard Kennedy …
sitename: Shorenstein Center
date: 2025-03-13
categories: ['News']
license: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

The Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy is pleased to announce that [ The Washington Post’s Opinions series “Who is Government?”](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interactive/2025/who-is-government/) is the winner of the inaugural

[Goldsmith Prize for Explanatory Reporting](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-explanatory-reporting/). The prize will be awarded at the

[2025 Goldsmith Awards ceremony on April 3](https://goldsmithawards.org/ceremony/2025/)at the JFK Jr. Forum at Harvard Kennedy School.

“This new prize was created to honor journalism that does the hard work of explaining essential institutions: how does the government actually work, who are the players, what is the essence of serving the public,” said Shorenstein Director Nancy Gibbs. “The team at *The Washington Post* captured the extraordinary work of the ordinary people who commit to making our lives better, safer, freer. As budgets are slashed and entire departments dissolved, I can think of no better time to tell their stories.”

Seven writers — Michael Lewis, Casey Cep, Dave Eggers, John Lanchester, Geraldine Brooks, Sarah Vowell, and W. Kamau Bell — were “set loose on the federal bureaucracy” and given the same brief: find a story about public service. Each piece, taken together, helped shine a light on the value of government work and the dedicated civil servants that are rarely written about or celebrated:

[Lewis found an engineer in the Bureau of Mines](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interactive/2024/michael-lewis-chris-marks-the-canary-who-is-government/) who singlehandedly revolutionized mining safety.

[Cep discovered an official at Veterans Affairs](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interactive/2024/casey-cep-ronald-walters-the-sentinel-wh…

# The Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting

## About the award

The annual Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting honors investigative reporting that best promotes more effective and ethical conduct of government, the making of public policy, or the practice of politics. The winner receives $25,000, and five finalists receive $10,000. Prize money is paid directly to the journalists, not the news organizations. While the subject can address issues of foreign policy, a submission qualifies only if it has an impact on public policy in the United States at the national, regional or local level.

Financial support for the Goldsmith Awards Program is provided by an annual grant from the Goldsmith Fund of the Greenfield Foundation. The program is administered by the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University’s Kennedy School of Government.

## Criteria and Rules

### Criteria

The annual Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting honors investigative reporting that best promotes more effective and ethical conduct of government, the making of public policy, or the practice of politics. The winner receives $25,000, and five finalists receive $10,000. While the subject can address issues of foreign policy, a submission qualifies only if it has an impact on public policy in the United States at the national, regional or local level. Entries from small and mid-size publications and comparable broadcast/online outlets are encouraged.

### Prize Money

The winning entry receives $25,000, and five finalist entries receive $10,000 each. Prize money is paid directly to credited authors of the winning/nominated entries, not their organizations.

Each year the awards honor six reporting teams (five finalists and one winner) for the Investigative Reporting Prize, one award for the Explanatory Reporting Prize, and two awards for books published in the last year on a topic at the intersection of media, politics, and public policy.The 2025 Career Awardee for Excellence in Journalism is Anderson Cooper, award-winning CNN anchor and CBS 60 Minutes correspondent. Cooper will be the featured speaker at this year’s ceremony, he will share his insights in a “fireside chat” with Shorenstein Center Director Nancy Gibbs, followed by a brief question-and-answer session with the audience.The in-person event will be livestreamed at GoldsmithAwards.org and ShorensteinCenter.org.More information on The Goldsmith Awards Program can be found here: https://goldsmithawards.org/Sponsored by: Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy

# 2025 Goldsmith Awards Ceremony

### Description

The annual Goldsmith Awards, presented by the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics, and Public Policy at Harvard Kennedy School, honors public service journalism that has had an impact on United States public policy and the functioning of government. Each year the awards honor six reporting teams (five finalists and one winner) for the [Investigative Reporting Prize](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-investigative-reporting/), one award for the [Explanatory Reporting Prize](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-explanatory-reporting/), and [two awards for books](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-book-prize/) published in the last year on a topic at the intersection of media, politics, and public policy.

[The 2025 Career Awardee for Excellence in Journalism is Anderson Cooper](https://shorensteincenter.org/anderson-cooper-honored-2025-goldsmith-career-award-excellence-journalism/), award-winning CNN anchor and CBS 60 Minutes correspondent. Cooper will be the featured speaker at this yea…

# 2025 Goldsmith Awards Ceremony

### Description

The annual Goldsmith Awards, presented by the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics, and Public Policy at Harvard Kennedy School, honors public service journalism that has had an impact on United States public policy and the functioning of government. Each year the awards honor six reporting teams (five finalists and one winner) for the [Investigative Reporting Prize](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-investigative-reporting/), one award for the [Explanatory Reporting Prize](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-explanatory-reporting/), and [two awards for books](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-book-prize/) published in the last year on a topic at the intersection of media, politics, and public policy.

[The 2025 Career Awardee for Excellence in Journalism is Anderson Cooper](https://shorensteincenter.org/anderson-cooper-honored-2025-goldsmith-career-award-excellence-journalism/), award-winning CNN anchor and CBS 60 Minutes correspondent. Cooper will be the featured speaker at this yea…

content.snippet:
---
title: Announcing the winner of the inaugural Goldsmith Prize for Explanatory Reporting | Shorenstein Center
url: https://shorensteincenter.org/announcing-winner-inaugural-goldsmith-prize-explanatory-reporting/
hostname: shorensteincenter.org
description: The Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy is pleased to announce that The Washington Post’s Opinions series “Who is Government?” is the winner of the inaugural Goldsmith Prize for Explanatory Reporting. The prize will be awarded at the 2025 Goldsmith Awards ceremony on April 3 at the JFK Jr. Forum at Harvard Kennedy …
sitename: Shorenstein Center
date: 2025-03-13
categories: ['News']
license: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0
---
The Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy is pleased to announce that [ The Washington Post’s Opinions series “Who is Government?”](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interactive/2025/who-is-government/) is the winner of the inaugural

[Goldsmith Prize for Explanatory Reporting](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-explanatory-reporting/). The prize will be awarded at the

[2025 Goldsmith Awards ceremony on April 3](https://goldsmithawards.org/ceremony/2025/)at the JFK Jr. Forum at Harvard Kennedy School.

“This new prize was created to honor journalism that does the hard work of explaining essential institutions: how does the government actually work, who are the players, what is the essence of serving the public,” said Shorenstein Director Nancy Gibbs. “The team at *The Washington Post* captured the extraordinary work of the ordinary people who commit to making our lives better, safer, freer. As budgets are slashed and entire departments dissolved, I can think of no better time to tell their stories.”

Seven writers — Michael Lewis, Casey Cep, Dave Eggers, John Lanchester, Geraldine Brooks, Sarah Vowell, and W. Kamau Bell — were “set loose on the federal bureaucracy” and given the same brief: find a story about public service. Each piece, taken together, helped shine a light on the value of government work and the dedicated civil servants that are rarely written about or celebrated:

[Lewis found an engineer in the Bureau of Mines](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interactive/2024/michael-lewis-chris-marks-the-canary-who-is-government/) who singlehandedly revolutionized mining safety.

[Cep discovered an official at Veterans Affairs](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interactive/2024/casey-cep-ronald-walters-the-sentinel-wh…

[Truncated preview: showing 312 words out of ~567. Full content available via `btf_extract_evidence`.]

messages.content:
Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will Fast and Fatal win the 2025 Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting?
Background: The Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting is a $25,000 award for journalists administered by the Shorenstein Center at Harvard University, recognizing excellence in investigative reporting that promotes better government.

'Fast and Fatal' is one of the finalists for the 2025 prize. This entry was produced by Jennifer Gollan and Susie Neilson of The San Francisco Chronicle.

The winner will be announced on April 3, 2025.
Resolution criteria: This question will resolve as YES if 'Fast and Fatal' is announced as the winner of the 2025 Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting, according to official website or social media accounts. Otherwise, it will resolve as NO.
Fine print: If no winner is announced before April 8, 2025 or if multiple finalists are announced as winners, this question will be **annulled**.
present_date: 2025-03-25T16:46:03.595791


Make sure to use the tools at your disposal to gather relevant information before providing your final probability estimate.

You may reason through the problem, but you MUST end your response with:
FINAL PROBABILITY: [your decimal number between 0 and 1]

{"url": "https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-investigative-reporting/", "snippet": "---
title: The Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting | Goldsmith Awards
author: Jennifer Gollan; Susie Neilson; The San Francisco Chronicle
url: https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-investigative-reporting/
hostname: goldsmithawards.org
description: Criteria and Rules Criteria The annual Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting honors investigative reporting that best promotes more effective and ethical conduct of government, the making of public policy, or the practice of politics. The winner receives $25,000, and five finalists receive $10,000. While the subject can address issues of foreign policy, a submission qualifies […]
sitename: Goldsmith Awards
date: 2025-03-05
---
# The Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting

## About the award

The annual Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting honors investigative reporting that best promotes more effective and ethical conduct of government, the making of public policy, or the practice of politics. The winner receives $25,000, and five finalists receive $10,000. Prize money is paid directly to the journalists, not the news organizations. While the subject can address issues of foreign policy, a submission qualifies only if it has an impact on public policy in the United States at the national, regional or local level.

Financial support for the Goldsmith Awards Program is provided by an annual grant from the Goldsmith Fund of the Greenfield Foundation. The program is administered by the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University’s Kennedy School of Government.

## Criteria and Rules

### Criteria

The annual Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting honors investigative reporting that best promotes more effective and ethical conduct of government, the making of public policy, or the practice of politics. The winner receives $25,000, and five finalists receive $10,000. While the subject can address issues of foreign policy, a submission qualifies only if it has an impact on public policy in the United States at the national, regional or local level. Entries from small and mid-size publications and comparable broadcast/online outlets are encouraged.

### Prize Money

The winning entry receives $25,000, and five finalist entries receive $10,000 each. Prize money is paid directly to credited authors of the winning/nominated entries, not their organizations.

#### Submission Info

Submissions for the 2025 Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporti…

# Announcements

The Goldsmith Awards Program, launched in 1991, has as its goal the encouragement of a more insightful and spirited public debate about government, politics and the press.

The Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy is pleased to announce that [ The Washington Post’s Opinions series “Who is Government?”](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interactive/2025/who-is-government/) is the winner of the inaugural

[Goldsmith Prize for Explanatory Reporting](https://goldsmithawards.org/the-goldsmith-prize-for-explanatory-reporting/). The prize will be awarded at the

[2025 Goldsmith Awards ceremony on April 3](https://goldsmithawards.org/ceremony/2025/)at the JFK Jr. Forum at Harvard Kennedy School.

“This new prize was created to honor journalism that does the hard work of explaining essential institutions: how does the government actually work, who are the players, what is the essence of serving the public,” said Shorenstein Director Nancy Gibbs. “The team at *The Washington Post* captured the extraordinary work of the ordinary people who commit to making our lives better, safer, freer. As budgets are slashed and entire departments dissolved, I can think of no better time to tell their stories.”

Seven writers — Michael Lewis, Casey Cep, Dave Eggers, John Lanchester, Geraldine Brooks, Sarah Vowell, and W. Kamau Bell — were “set loose on the federal bureaucracy” and given the same brief: find a story about public service. Each piece, taken together, helped shine a light on the value of government work and the dedicated civil servants that are rarely written about or celebrated:

[Lewis found an engineer in the Bureau of Mines](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interactive/2024/michael-lewis-chris-marks-the-canary-who-is-government/) who singlehandedly revolutionized mining safety.

[Cep discovered an official at Veterans Affairs](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interactive/2024/casey-cep-ronald-walters-the-sentinel-wh…

[Truncated preview: showing 312 words out of ~567. messages.content:
Based on the information gathered, here are some key points:

1. **Finalists and Prize Structure**: The Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting honors investigative reporting that promotes effective and ethical government conduct. The winner receives $25,000, and five finalists receive $10,000 each. The prize is administered by the Shorenstein Center at Harvard University.

2. **Current Status**: 'Fast and Fatal' by Jennifer Gollan and Susie Neilson of The San Francisco Chronicle is one of the finalists for the 2025 prize. The winner will be announced on April 3, 2025.

3. **No Current Predictions or Announcements**: There are no current predictions or announcements indicating which finalist might win the prize. The information available does not provide any specific insights into the likelihood of 'Fast and Fatal' winning over other finalists.

Given the lack of specific predictions or insider information about the likelihood of 'Fast and Fatal' winning, it is challenging to assign a high probability to its success. However, being a finalist already indicates a strong entry.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.2
